Blurb
Overview
This module introduces students to a wide range of cell biology themes, including the functions of all the main subcellular compartments and organelles (e.g. plasma membrane, nucleus, endoplasmic reticulum, mitochondria, Golgi, centrosome, autophagosomes, lysosome, peroxisome, secretory vesicles and trafficking, ribosomes, cytoskeleton, molecular motors, intercellular junctions, extracellular matrix). Emphasis will also be given to membrane biophysics (ion gradients, ‘excitable’ systems), mechanotransduction, contractile protein systems and intracellular proteostasis. Taking general cell biology themes to the level of tissues and human body systems physiology, the module will cover a range of examples of specialised cell functions within organs, including the digestive, renal, respiratory, musculoskeletal, and neuroendocrine tissues. Regulation of tissue/organ function via neuronal and hormonal communication and signalling mechanisms to achieve physiological homeostasis will be another point of focus. Examples of diseases will be used to highlight malfunctioning of physiological systems from the tissue to the cell and molecular level. Furthermore, methods of studying cells and tissues will be explained in context, including imaging, electrophysiological and molecular biological techniques.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures, workshops and active learning tasks. Lectures will convey fundamental knowledge and include examples of applications from actual research publications, or the lecturer’s own research work.

There are two assessment in this module. The first assessment is a midterm assessment (40%) comprising a mixture of Multiple answer, multiple choice and extended matching item questions. The second assessment, is a written assessment, which consists of two parts: Section 1 - assessing cellular and systems physiology concepts (30%) and Section 2 - Data interpretation and understanding (30%)
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To enhance students’ understanding of the cellular and organ systems physiology required for healthy human existence.
2. To develop students’ knowledge of how cells and tissues are studied.
3. To raise students’ critical awareness to the challenges overcome in maintaining homeostasis and the communication interplay required.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Knowledge of the molecular physiology of cells and the physiology of organs on a systems level provides a fundamental basis for our understanding of the healthy body as well as disease-related mechanisms. Students will learn about a range of cellular functions, the roles of subcellular compartments, ranging from the nucleus to intracellular membrane compartments, plasma membrane and extracellular matrix, as well as dynamic molecular mechanisms like intracellular trafficking processes. Taking general cell biology to the organ systems level, this module will develop knowledge about the specialised functions of cells in specific human tissues and how the body regulates the various organ functions through communication pathways in a systemic way to achieve homeostasis. You will encounter various examples, including the digestive, renal, respiratory and neuroendocrine organs among others. Furthermore, you will be learning about a number of techniques and methods that are used to study the molecular biology of cells and the systems physiology of the body, including imaging techniques.

The module is taught through lectures and workshops, which are supported through directed reading/ multimedia.

There are two assessment in this module. The first assessment is a midterm assessment (40%) comprising a mixture of Multiple answer, multiple choice and extended matching item questions. The second assessment consists of two parts: Section 1 - assessing cellular and systems physiology concepts (30%) and Section 2 - Data interpretation and understanding (30%)
Outline Syllabus
1. Cellular and organelle structure/function – plasma membrane, nucleus; rER/sER, mitochondria, Golgi, centrosome, autophagosomes, lysosome, peroxisome, inter-organelle membrane contact sites, secretory vesicles and trafficking, ribosomes, cytoskeleton, molecular motors, intercellular junctions, extracellular matrix

2. Biophysics/Membrane - ionic gradients, buffering, electrophysiology, transport

3. Cellular dynamics: Trafficking mechanisms, proteostasis, contractility, mechanotransduction, membrane compartmentalisation

4. Human Physiology Systems – including but not limited to the following systems: Neuronal, musculoskeletal, cardiorespiratory, GI, etc…

5. Human Physiology Systems integrated - Homeostasis, neuroendocrine (Hypothalamus-Pituitary axes) and other hormone systems.

6. Studying cells and tissues - MRI, light microscopy, electrophysiology, etc…
Teaching and Learning Methods
Online Preparatory Material:
These will be in the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks which will be used to introduce key concepts. Providing an appropriate knowledge baseline, which prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.

Lectures:
The module will be taught through lectures with an emphasis towards active learning, detailed below. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 30 x 1 hour teaching sessions will be delivered over a twelve-week period.

Guided workshops: These will provide opportunities for students to work through formative assessment examples in the weeks which have summative assessments. There will be 4 x 1hour workshops distributed proportionally throughout the module.

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be accompanied by approx. 2 hours of independent study from online resources and texts, and it is expected that this learning is consolidated by 60 hours of independent learning that integrates material across the course. Encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of multimedia, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, revision study and work towards assessment.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE.

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). These will provide students prompts to discuss concepts and their application in small groups, which will promote deeper learning. These formative exercises will provide students with feedback/ feedforward on their learning. Highlighting areas which staff and students may wish to focus on in workshops, or students in their personal study time.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: Organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.

Attendance recorded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Cycle 1: On-line assessment – data analysis - computer marked (Multiple Choice Questions (MCQ), FiB, Multiple Answer Questions (MAQ), and Extended Matching Items (EMI)).
These modes of assessment will be used test knowledge, understanding, and application/ data analysis. Providing equity across the assessments to acknowledge differing learning styles. The assessment will be for 2 hours in total, split into two 60 min tests. The number of questions will be determined based on the complexity of the questions (i.e. reading time and information required). This will contribute 40% of the module mark. This is one assessment split into two sessions to help students with concentration. Thereby making the assessment inclusive

Cycle 2: Open-book extended written piece across the whole course, in two sections: section 1 - cellular and systems physiology concepts (30%). This test will consist of a series of 6 questions, each requiring extended written answers. Total length of assessment is 60 minutes and section 2 consists of a series of questions focussing on data interpretation and understanding, lasting 60 minutes (30%). Total for this cycle (60%)

Questions will be designed to reflect real world examples contributing to an authentic assessment strategy. The use of online assessment will aid development of digital fluency. Skills will be assessed by careful design of assessment questions such that independent extra reading and learning is required outside of the lectures. Feedback session after cycle 1 assessment will allow self-evaluation of performance and opportunity to act on this for cycle 2 assessment.

Students will be provided with formative examples of questions representative of those to be used in the assessment.

Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
This module introduces students to a wide range of cell biology themes, including the functions of all the main subcellular compartments and organelles (e.g. plasma membrane, nucleus, endoplasmic reticulum, mitochondria, Golgi, centrosome, autophagosomes, lysosome, peroxisome, secretory vesicles and trafficking, ribosomes, cytoskeleton, molecular motors, intercellular junctions, extracellular matrix). Emphasis will also be given to membrane biophysics (ion gradients, ‘excitable’ systems), mechanotransduction, contractile protein systems and intracellular proteostasis. Taking general cell biology themes to the level of tissues and human body systems physiology, the module will cover a range of examples of specialised cell functions within organs, including the digestive, renal, respiratory, musculoskeletal, and neuroendocrine tissues. Regulation of tissue/organ function via neuronal and hormonal communication and signalling mechanisms to achieve physiological homeostasis will be another point of focus. Examples of diseases will be used to highlight malfunctioning of physiological systems from the tissue to the cell and molecular level. Furthermore, methods of studying cells and tissues will be explained in context, including imaging, electrophysiological and molecular biological techniques.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures, workshops and active learning tasks. Lectures will convey fundamental knowledge and include examples of applications from actual research publications, or the lecturer’s own research work.

There are two assessment in this module. The first assessment is a midterm assessment (40%) comprising a mixture of Multiple answer, multiple choice and extended matching item questions. The second assessment, is a written assessment, which consists of two parts: Section 1 - assessing cellular and systems physiology concepts (30%) and Section 2 - Data interpretation and understanding (30%)
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To enhance students’ understanding of the cellular and organ systems physiology required for healthy human existence.
2. To develop students’ knowledge of how cells and tissues are studied.
3. To raise students’ critical awareness to the challenges overcome in maintaining homeostasis and the communication interplay required.

Knowledge of the molecular physiology of cells and the physiology of organs on a systems level provides a fundamental basis for our understanding of the healthy body as well as disease-related mechanisms. The second assessment consists of two parts: Section 1 - assessing cellular and systems physiology concepts (30%) and Section 2 - Data interpretation and understanding (30%)

1. Cellular and organelle structure/function – plasma membrane, nucleus; rER/sER, mitochondria, Golgi, centrosome, autophagosomes, lysosome, peroxisome, inter-organelle membrane contact sites, secretory vesicles and trafficking, ribosomes, cytoskeleton, molecular motors, intercellular junctions, extracellular matrix

4. Human Physiology Systems – including but not limited to the following systems: Neuronal, musculoskeletal, cardiorespiratory, GI, etc…

5. Human Physiology Systems integrated - Homeostasis, neuroendocrine (Hypothalamus-Pituitary axes) and other hormone systems.

6. Studying cells and tissues - MRI, light microscopy, electrophysiology, etc…

Online Preparatory Material:
These will be in the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks which will be used to introduce key concepts. Providing an appropriate knowledge baseline, which prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.

The module will be taught through lectures with an emphasis towards active learning, detailed below. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 30 x 1 hour teaching sessions will be delivered over a twelve-week period.

Guided workshops: These will provide opportunities for students to work through formative assessment examples in the weeks which have summative assessments. There will be 4 x 1hour workshops distributed proportionally throughout the module.

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be accompanied by approx. 2 hours of independent study from online resources and texts, and it is expected that this learning is consolidated by 60 hours of independent learning that integrates material across the course. Encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of multimedia, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, revision study and work towards assessment.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.

Assessment Strategy
Cycle 1: On-line assessment – data analysis - computer marked (Multiple Choice Questions (MCQ), FiB, Multiple Answer Questions (MAQ), and Extended Matching Items (EMI)).
These modes of assessment will be used test knowledge, understanding, and application/ data analysis. Providing equity across the assessments to acknowledge differing learning styles. The assessment will be for 2 hours in total, split into two 60 min tests. The number of questions will be determined based on the complexity of the questions (i.e. reading time and information required). This will contribute 40% of the module mark. This is one assessment split into two sessions to help students with concentration. Thereby making the assessment inclusive

Cycle 2: Open-book extended written piece across the whole course, in two sections: section 1 - cellular and systems physiology concepts (30%). This test will consist of a series of 6 questions, each requiring extended written answers. Total length of assessment is 60 minutes and section 2 consists of a series of questions focussing on data interpretation and understanding, lasting 60 minutes (30%). Total for this cycle (60%)

Questions will be designed to reflect real world examples contributing to an authentic assessment strategy. The use of online assessment will aid development of digital fluency. Skills will be assessed by careful design of assessment questions such that independent extra reading and learning is required outside of the lectures. Feedback session after cycle 1 assessment will allow self-evaluation of performance and opportunity to act on this for cycle 2 assessment.

Students will be provided with formative examples of questions representative of those to be used in the assessment.

Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Cellular and Systems Physiology 2025-26

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 5
Credits:15
Module Code:BIOS214

Blurb
Overview
This module introduces students to a wide range of cell biology themes, including the functions of all the main subcellular compartments and organelles (e.g. plasma membrane, nucleus, endoplasmic reticulum, mitochondria, Golgi, centrosome, autophagosomes, lysosome, peroxisome, secretory vesicles and trafficking, ribosomes, cytoskeleton, molecular motors, intercellular junctions, extracellular matrix). Emphasis will also be given to membrane biophysics (ion gradients, ‘excitable’ systems), mechanotransduction, contractile protein systems and intracellular proteostasis. Taking general cell biology themes to the level of tissues and human body systems physiology, the module will cover a range of examples of specialised cell functions within organs, including the digestive, renal, respiratory, musculoskeletal, and neuroendocrine tissues. Regulation of tissue/organ function via neuronal and hormonal communication and signalling mechanisms to achieve physiological homeostasis will be another point of focus. Examples of diseases will be used to highlight malfunctioning of physiological systems from the tissue to the cell and molecular level. Furthermore, methods of studying cells and tissues will be explained in context, including imaging, electrophysiological and molecular biological techniques.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures, workshops and active learning tasks. Lectures will convey fundamental knowledge and include examples of applications from actual research publications, or the lecturer’s own research work.

There are two assessment in this module. The first assessment is a midterm assessment (40%) comprising a mixture of Multiple answer, multiple choice and extended matching item questions. The second assessment, is a written assessment, which consists of two parts: Section 1 - assessing cellular and systems physiology concepts (30%) and Section 2 - Data interpretation and understanding (30%)
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To enhance students’ understanding of the cellular and organ systems physiology required for healthy human existence.
2. To develop students’ knowledge of how cells and tissues are studied.
3. To raise students’ critical awareness to the challenges overcome in maintaining homeostasis and the communication interplay required.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Knowledge of the molecular physiology of cells and the physiology of organs on a systems level provides a fundamental basis for our understanding of the healthy body as well as disease-related mechanisms. Students will learn about a range of cellular functions, the roles of subcellular compartments, ranging from the nucleus to intracellular membrane compartments, plasma membrane and extracellular matrix, as well as dynamic molecular mechanisms like intracellular trafficking processes. Taking general cell biology to the organ systems level, this module will develop knowledge about the specialised functions of cells in specific human tissues and how the body regulates the various organ functions through communication pathways in a systemic way to achieve homeostasis. You will encounter various examples, including the digestive, renal, respiratory and neuroendocrine organs among others. Furthermore, you will be learning about a number of techniques and methods that are used to study the molecular biology of cells and the systems physiology of the body, including imaging techniques.

The module is taught through lectures and workshops, which are supported through directed reading/ multimedia.

There are two assessment in this module. The first assessment is a midterm assessment (40%) comprising a mixture of Multiple answer, multiple choice and extended matching item questions. The second assessment consists of two parts: Section 1 - assessing cellular and systems physiology concepts (30%) and Section 2 - Data interpretation and understanding (30%)
Outline Syllabus
1. Cellular and organelle structure/function – plasma membrane, nucleus; rER/sER, mitochondria, Golgi, centrosome, autophagosomes, lysosome, peroxisome, inter-organelle membrane contact sites, secretory vesicles and trafficking, ribosomes, cytoskeleton, molecular motors, intercellular junctions, extracellular matrix

2. Biophysics/Membrane - ionic gradients, buffering, electrophysiology, transport

3. Cellular dynamics: Trafficking mechanisms, proteostasis, contractility, mechanotransduction, membrane compartmentalisation

4. Human Physiology Systems – including but not limited to the following systems: Neuronal, musculoskeletal, cardiorespiratory, GI, etc…

5. Human Physiology Systems integrated - Homeostasis, neuroendocrine (Hypothalamus-Pituitary axes) and other hormone systems.

6. Studying cells and tissues - MRI, light microscopy, electrophysiology, etc…
Teaching and Learning Methods
Online Preparatory Material:
These will be in the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks which will be used to introduce key concepts. Providing an appropriate knowledge baseline, which prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.

Lectures:
The module will be taught through lectures with an emphasis towards active learning, detailed below. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 30 x 1 hour teaching sessions will be delivered over a twelve-week period.

Guided workshops: These will provide opportunities for students to work through formative assessment examples in the weeks which have summative assessments. There will be 4 x 1hour workshops distributed proportionally throughout the module.

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be accompanied by approx. 2 hours of independent study from online resources and texts, and it is expected that this learning is consolidated by 60 hours of independent learning that integrates material across the course. Encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of multimedia, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, revision study and work towards assessment.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE.

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). These will provide students prompts to discuss concepts and their application in small groups, which will promote deeper learning. These formative exercises will provide students with feedback/ feedforward on their learning. Highlighting areas which staff and students may wish to focus on in workshops, or students in their personal study time.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: Organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.

Attendance recorded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Cycle 1: On-line assessment – data analysis - computer marked (Multiple Choice Questions (MCQ), FiB, Multiple Answer Questions (MAQ), and Extended Matching Items (EMI)).
These modes of assessment will be used test knowledge, understanding, and application/ data analysis. Providing equity across the assessments to acknowledge differing learning styles. The assessment will be for 2 hours in total, split into two 60 min tests. The number of questions will be determined based on the complexity of the questions (i.e. reading time and information required). This will contribute 40% of the module mark. This is one assessment split into two sessions to help students with concentration. Thereby making the assessment inclusive

Cycle 2: Open-book extended written piece across the whole course, in two sections: section 1 - cellular and systems physiology concepts (30%). This test will consist of a series of 6 questions, each requiring extended written answers. Total length of assessment is 60 minutes and section 2 consists of a series of questions focussing on data interpretation and understanding, lasting 60 minutes (30%). Total for this cycle (60%)

Questions will be designed to reflect real world examples contributing to an authentic assessment strategy. The use of online assessment will aid development of digital fluency. Skills will be assessed by careful design of assessment questions such that independent extra reading and learning is required outside of the lectures. Feedback session after cycle 1 assessment will allow self-evaluation of performance and opportunity to act on this for cycle 2 assessment.

Students will be provided with formative examples of questions representative of those to be used in the assessment.

Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Taking general cell biology to the organ systems level, this module will develop knowledge about the specialised functions of cells in specific human tissues and how the body regulates the various organ functions through communication pathways in a systemic way to achieve homeostasis. You will encounter various examples, including the digestive, renal, respiratory and neuroendocrine organs among others. Furthermore, you will be learning about a number of techniques and methods that are used to study the molecular biology of cells and the systems physiology of the body, including imaging techniques.

The module is taught through lectures and workshops, which are supported through directed reading/ multimedia.

There are two assessment in this module. The first assessment is a midterm assessment (40%) comprising a mixture of Multiple answer, multiple choice and extended matching item questions. The second assessment consists of two parts: Section 1 - assessing cellular and systems physiology concepts (30%) and Section 2 - Data interpretation and understanding (30%)
Outline Syllabus
1. Cellular and organelle structure/function – plasma membrane, nucleus; rER/sER, mitochondria, Golgi, centrosome, autophagosomes, lysosome, peroxisome, inter-organelle membrane contact sites, secretory vesicles and trafficking, ribosomes, cytoskeleton, molecular motors, intercellular junctions, extracellular matrix

2. Biophysics/Membrane - ionic gradients, buffering, electrophysiology, transport

3. Cellular dynamics: Trafficking mechanisms, proteostasis, contractility, mechanotransduction, membrane compartmentalisation

4. Human Physiology Systems – including but not limited to the following systems: Neuronal, musculoskeletal, cardiorespiratory, GI, etc…

5. Human Physiology Systems integrated - Homeostasis, neuroendocrine (Hypothalamus-Pituitary axes) and other hormone systems.

6. Studying cells and tissues - MRI, light microscopy, electrophysiology, etc…
Teaching and Learning Methods
Online Preparatory Material:
These will be in the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks which will be used to introduce key concepts. Providing an appropriate knowledge baseline, which prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.

Lectures:
The module will be taught through lectures with an emphasis towards active learning, detailed below. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 30 x 1 hour teaching sessions will be delivered over a twelve-week period.

Guided workshops: These will provide opportunities for students to work through formative assessment examples in the weeks which have summative assessments. There will be 4 x 1hour workshops distributed proportionally throughout the module.

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be accompanied by approx. 2 hours of independent study from online resources and texts, and it is expected that this learning is consolidated by 60 hours of independent learning that integrates material across the course. Encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of multimedia, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, revision study and work towards assessment.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE.

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). These will provide students prompts to discuss concepts and their application in small groups, which will promote deeper learning. These formative exercises will provide students with feedback/ feedforward on their learning. Highlighting areas which staff and students may wish to focus on in workshops, or students in their personal study time.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment strategies. Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology.

Global citizenship: Organisms, their development, their varied physiology, and immunity, infection, and therapeutics are studied at a global scale. Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.

Attendance recorded: Yes

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Cycle 1: On-line assessment – data analysis - computer marked (Multiple Choice Questions (MCQ), FiB, Multiple Answer Questions (MAQ), and Extended Matching Items (EMI)).
These modes of assessment will be used test knowledge, understanding, and application/ data analysis. Providing equity across the assessments to acknowledge differing learning styles. The assessment will be for 2 hours in total, split into two 60 min tests. The number of questions will be determined based on the complexity of the questions (i.e. reading time and information required). This will contribute 40% of the module mark. This is one assessment split into two sessions to help students with concentration. Thereby making the assessment inclusive

Cycle 2: Open-book extended written piece across the whole course, in two sections: section 1 - cellular and systems physiology concepts (30%). This test will consist of a series of 6 questions, each requiring extended written answers. Total length of assessment is 60 minutes and section 2 consists of a series of questions focussing on data interpretation and understanding, lasting 60 minutes (30%). Total for this cycle (60%)

Questions will be designed to reflect real world examples contributing to an authentic assessment strategy. The use of online assessment will aid development of digital fluency. Skills will be assessed by careful design of assessment questions such that independent extra reading and learning is required outside of the lectures. Feedback session after cycle 1 assessment will allow self-evaluation of performance and opportunity to act on this for cycle 2 assessment.

Students will be provided with formative examples of questions representative of those to be used in the assessment.

Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
This module introduces students to a wide range of cell biology themes, including the functions of all the main subcellular compartments and organelles (e.g. plasma membrane, nucleus, endoplasmic reticulum, mitochondria, Golgi, centrosome, autophagosomes, lysosome, peroxisome, secretory vesicles and trafficking, ribosomes, cytoskeleton, molecular motors, intercellular junctions, extracellular matrix). Emphasis will also be given to membrane biophysics (ion gradients, ‘excitable’ systems), mechanotransduction, contractile protein systems and intracellular proteostasis. Taking general cell biology themes to the level of tissues and human body systems physiology, the module will cover a range of examples of specialised cell functions within organs, including the digestive, renal, respiratory, musculoskeletal, and neuroendocrine tissues. Regulation of tissue/organ function via neuronal and hormonal communication and signalling mechanisms to achieve physiological homeostasis will be another point of focus. Examples of diseases will be used to highlight malfunctioning of physiological systems from the tissue to the cell and molecular level. Furthermore, methods of studying cells and tissues will be explained in context, including imaging, electrophysiological and molecular biological techniques.

The module will be taught through a combination of lectures, workshops and active learning tasks. Lectures will convey fundamental knowledge and include examples of applications from actual research publications, or the lecturer’s own research work.

There are two assessment in this module. The first assessment is a midterm assessment (40%) comprising a mixture of Multiple answer, multiple choice and extended matching item questions. The second assessment, is a written assessment, which consists of two parts: Section 1 - assessing cellular and systems physiology concepts (30%) and Section 2 - Data interpretation and understanding (30%)
Educational Aims
The aims of this module are:

1. To enhance students’ understanding of the cellular and organ systems physiology required for healthy human existence.
2. To develop students’ knowledge of how cells and tissues are studied.
3. To raise students’ critical awareness to the challenges overcome in maintaining homeostasis and the communication interplay required.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Knowledge of the molecular physiology of cells and the physiology of organs on a systems level provides a fundamental basis for our understanding of the healthy body as well as disease-related mechanisms. Students will learn about a range of cellular functions, the roles of subcellular compartments, ranging from the nucleus to intracellular membrane compartments, plasma membrane and extracellular matrix, as well as dynamic molecular mechanisms like intracellular trafficking processes. Taking general cell biology to the organ systems level, this module will develop knowledge about the specialised functions of cells in specific human tissues and how the body regulates the various organ functions through communication pathways in a systemic way to achieve homeostasis. You will encounter various examples, including the digestive, renal, respiratory and neuroendocrine organs among others. Furthermore, you will be learning about a number of techniques and methods that are used to study the molecular biology of cells and the systems physiology of the body, including imaging techniques.

The module is taught through lectures and workshops, which are supported through directed reading/ multimedia.

There are two assessment in this module. The first assessment is a midterm assessment (40%) comprising a mixture of Multiple answer, multiple choice and extended matching item questions. The second assessment consists of two parts: Section 1 - assessing cellular and systems physiology concepts (30%) and Section 2 - Data interpretation and understanding (30%)
Outline Syllabus
1. Cellular and organelle structure/function – plasma membrane, nucleus; rER/sER, mitochondria, Golgi, centrosome, autophagosomes, lysosome, peroxisome, inter-organelle membrane contact sites, secretory vesicles and trafficking, ribosomes, cytoskeleton, molecular motors, intercellular junctions, extracellular matrix

2. Biophysics/Membrane - ionic gradients, buffering, electrophysiology, transport

3. Cellular dynamics: Trafficking mechanisms, proteostasis, contractility, mechanotransduction, membrane compartmentalisation

4. Human Physiology Systems – including but not limited to the following systems: Neuronal, musculoskeletal, cardiorespiratory, GI, etc…

5. Human Physiology Systems integrated - Homeostasis, neuroendocrine (Hypothalamus-Pituitary axes) and other hormone systems.

6. Studying cells and tissues - MRI, light microscopy, electrophysiology, etc…
Teaching and Learning Methods
Online Preparatory Material:
These will be in the form of online reading, multimedia and small tasks which will be used to introduce key concepts. Providing an appropriate knowledge baseline, which prepares students for the block of upcoming lectures.

Lectures:
The module will be taught through lectures with an emphasis towards active learning, detailed below. These will cover the core module content and characterised by interactive group discussions and activities to enhance understanding of key concepts. 30 x 1 hour teaching sessions will be delivered over a twelve-week period.

Guided workshops: These will provide opportunities for students to work through formative assessment examples in the weeks which have summative assessments. There will be 4 x 1hour workshops distributed proportionally throughout the module.

Independent learning: Each teaching session will be accompanied by approx. 2 hours of independent study from online resources and texts, and it is expected that this learning is consolidated by 60 hours of independent learning that integrates material across the course. Encompasses all unscheduled learning activities, e.g., directed reading, use of multimedia, self-directed learning, in preparation for lectures, revision study and work towards assessment.

The nature and implementation of this method is specifically designed to incorporate the hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework, in the following ways:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active/ connected scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Core concepts are contextualised with publications of recent scientific research. Assessment submissions from learners should be evidence-based by their exploration of primary literature, and suitably referenced.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Resource templates use accessible fonts and colour schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans. Lectures are recorded and available on the VLE.

Active learning: Structured participation will be interactive, using quizzes (e.g. PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, Kahoot) and collaborative, interactive tools (e.g. Padlet, Miro). These will provide students prompts to discuss concepts and their application in small groups, which will promote deeper learning. These formative exercises will provide students with feedback/ feedforward on their learning. Highlighting areas which staff and students may wish to focus on in workshops, or students in their personal study time.

Data interpretation is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning etc. The online tests require students to lead their own enquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base which will be applied to subsequent modules. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Confidence: This is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing of ideas and expertise.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. The VLE is used for formative and summative assessment in the form of interactive quizzes. Assessment activity also requires students to develop competency with digital technology.

Our curriculum embeds values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritise representation of diverse imagery and use scientific cases which reflect issues affecting marginalised communities.

Attendance recorded: Yes

Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Cycle 1: On-line assessment – data analysis - computer marked (Multiple Choice Questions (MCQ), FiB, Multiple Answer Questions (MAQ), and Extended Matching Items (EMI)).
These modes of assessment will be used test knowledge, understanding, and application/ data analysis. Providing equity across the assessments to acknowledge differing learning styles. The assessment will be for 2 hours in total, split into two 60 min tests. The number of questions will be determined based on the complexity of the questions (i.e. reading time and information required). This will contribute 40% of the module mark. This is one assessment split into two sessions to help students with concentration. Thereby making the assessment inclusive

Cycle 2: Open-book extended written piece across the whole course, in two sections: section 1 - cellular and systems physiology concepts (30%). This test will consist of a series of 6 questions, each requiring extended written answers. Total length of assessment is 60 minutes and section 2 consists of a series of questions focussing on data interpretation and understanding, lasting 60 minutes (30%). Total for this cycle (60%)

Questions will be designed to reflect real world examples contributing to an authentic assessment strategy. The use of online assessment will aid development of digital fluency. Skills will be assessed by careful design of assessment questions such that independent extra reading and learning is required outside of the lectures. Feedback session after cycle 1 assessment will allow self-evaluation of performance and opportunity to act on this for cycle 2 assessment.

Students will be provided with formative examples of questions representative of those to be used in the assessment.

Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
